procedure: Arthroscopic debridement of partial-thickness rotator cuff tear, right shoulder
extraction_data.summary: 54-year-old male with chronic impingement symptoms and partial-thickness supraspinatus tear not improved with conservative treatment. Patient underwent arthroscopic subacromial decompression and debridement of partial-thickness rotator cuff tear in the right shoulder. Diagnostic arthroscopy revealed fraying of the bursal surface of the supraspinatus tendon without full-thickness involvement, and appropriate debridement was performed.

primary_reasons: Insufficient documentation of function-limiting pain duration (6 months required)
No documentation of abnormal physical examination findings compared to non-involved side
No documentation of positive impingement tests (Neer or Hawkins-Kennedy)
Insufficient details on non-surgical management duration (3 months required)
No documentation of advanced imaging findings

requirement_checklist.suggestion: Document specific duration of function-limiting pain (must be at least 6 months)

requirement_checklist.missing_to_meet: Documentation of abnormal shoulder physical examination findings compared to non-involved side
requirement_checklist.suggestion: Document specific range of motion limitations or strength deficits compared to left shoulder

requirement_checklist.missing_to_meet: Documentation of positive Neer Impingement Test or Hawkins-Kennedy Impingement Test
requirement_checklist.suggestion: Document results of specific impingement tests performed

requirement_checklist.missing_to_meet: Documentation of provider-directed non-surgical management for at least 3 months
requirement_checklist.suggestion: Specify duration and details of therapy and injections attempted

requirement_checklist.missing_to_meet: Documentation of advanced diagnostic imaging study findings
requirement_checklist.suggestion: Include MRI or CT findings that support the diagnosis and need for procedure

requirement_checklist.missing_to_meet: Documentation that other potential pathological conditions have been excluded
requirement_checklist.suggestion: Document evaluation and exclusion of other conditions like fracture, thoracic outlet syndrome, etc.

compliance_actions: Document specific duration of symptoms (at least 6 months required)

full_source.description: Diagnostic arthroscopy as a stand-alone procedure for evaluation of shoulder pathology when advanced imaging is inconclusive (Evidence: pg no: 4, L154-L155)

documentation: Function-limiting pain for at least six (6) months in duration (Evidence: pg no: 4, L156-L157)
Abnormal shoulder physical examination findings compared to non-involved side including functionally limited range of motion or measurable loss in strength (Evidence: pg no: 4, L158-L161)
Positive Neer Impingement Test or Hawkins-Kennedy Impingement Test (Evidence: pg no: 4, L162)
Failure of provider-directed non-surgical management for at least three (3) months in duration (Evidence: pg no: 4, L163-L164)

exclusions: Any other indication or condition (Evidence: pg no: 5, L171-L172)
In-office diagnostic arthroscopy (e.g., Mi-Eye™, VisionScope®) - considered experimental, investigational, or unproven (Evidence: pg no: 5, L175-L176)

full_source.description: Repair of Grade 2 or 3 partial-thickness or full-thickness rotator cuff tears with specific orthopedic test requirements (Evidence: pg no: 7-8, L283-L323)
full_source.scope: Arthroscopic or open rotator cuff repair (Evidence: pg no: 7, L283)

documentation: Function-limiting pain (Evidence: pg no: 7, L285-L287)
Individual demonstrates functionally limited range of motion OR measurable loss of strength of the rotator cuff musculature (Evidence: pg no: 7, L288-L291)

ONE or MORE positive orthopedic tests/signs including Drop Arm Test, Painful Arc Test, Jobe or Empty Can Test, External Rotation Lag Sign, Internal Rotation Lag Sign, Lift-Off Test, Bear Hug Test, Belly-Press Test, Neer Impingement Test, Hawkins-Kennedy Impingement Test, Hornblower Test (Evidence: pg no: 7-8, L292-L303)

Failure of provider-directed non-surgical management for at least three (3) months in duration, except for discrete traumatic event resulting in acute full-thickness rotator cuff tear (Evidence: pg no: 8, L304-L307)

Advanced diagnostic imaging demonstrates a Grade 2 or 3 partial-thickness rotator cuff tear (Ellman classification) or a full-thickness rotator cuff tear (Cofield classification) (Evidence: pg no: 8, L317-L320)

Other potential pathological conditions have been excluded including fracture, thoracic outlet syndrome, brachial plexus disorders, referred neck pain and advanced glenohumeral osteoarthritis (Evidence: pg no: 8, L321-L323)

exclusions: Any other indication or condition (Evidence: pg no: 8, L326-L327)
Superior capsular reconstruction using any type of graft - considered experimental, investigational, or unproven (Evidence: pg no: 8, L331-L332)

codes.description: Repair of ruptured musculotendinous cuff (e.g. rotator cuff) open; acute (Evidence: pg no: 13, L541)
Repair of ruptured musculotendinous cuff (e.g. rotator cuff) open; chronic (Evidence: pg no: 13, L542)
Reconstruction of complete shoulder (rotator) cuff avulsion, chronic (includes acromioplasty) (Evidence: pg no: 13, L544)
Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; with rotator cuff repair (Evidence: pg no: 14, L585)

full_source.notes: Conservative management requirement waived for acute traumatic tears, but required if fatty infiltration and/or muscle atrophy present (Evidence: pg no: 8, L308-L316)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.description: Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty is similar to standard arthroplasty in that both components of the joint are replaced but the ball and socket portions of the joint are reversed, allowing the deltoid muscle to assume partial function of the rotator cuff. full_source.section_title: Reverse Shoulder Arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 10, L300)
names: Reverse Shoulder Arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 10, L300)
Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 7, L178)
full_source.description: Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty is similar to standard arthroplasty in that both components of the joint are replaced but the ball and socket portions of the joint are reversed, allowing the deltoid muscle to assume partial function of the rotator cuff. This procedure is typically utilized when there is concomitant rotator cuff disease. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L178-L180)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of a congenital condition, acute or traumatic event such as fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 7, L181-L183)

documentation: Reconstruction after a tumor resection (Evidence: pg no: 10, L302)
Glenohumeral osteoarthritis with irreparable rotator cuff tear (Evidence: pg no: 10, L303)
Glenoid bone stock inadequate to support a glenoid prosthesis (Evidence: pg no: 10, L304)
Failed hemiarthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 10, L305)
Failed total shoulder arthroplasty with non-repairable rotator cuff (Evidence: pg no: 10, L306)
Shoulder fracture that is not repairable or cannot be reconstructed with other techniques (Evidence: pg no: 10, L307)
Deficient rotator cuff with limited ability to actively flex the upper extremity to 90 degrees against gravity (Evidence: pg no: 10, L310-L311)

full_source.notes: Considered medically necessary for ANY of the listed indications when associated with pain and functional impairment. (Evidence: pg no: 10, L301)

full_source.section_title: Rotator Cuff Repair (Evidence: pg no: 14, L461)
names: Rotator Cuff Repair (Evidence: pg no: 14, L461)
full_source.description: Rotator cuff repair is considered medically necessary for acute full thickness tear, chronic or degenerative full thickness tear, and partial thickness tear when specific criteria are met. (Evidence: pg no: 14, L465, L478, L493)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroscopy and open procedures when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L373-L374)

documentation: For acute full thickness tear: Traumatic injury within the preceding 3 months with no preexisting shoulder pain (Evidence: pg no: 14, L467-L468)
Shoulder pain ≥ 4 on the VAS scale exacerbated by movement (Evidence: pg no: 14, L469)
Weakness of rotator cuff muscle(s) (Evidence: pg no: 14, L470)

Physical exam demonstrating a positive response to at least ONE of the following tests: Drop arm test, Painful arc test, Full/empty can test, Weakness of external/internal rotation (Evidence: pg no: 14, L471-L475)
Advanced imaging confirms features of an acute full thickness or high-grade partial tear (Evidence: pg no: 14, L476)

exclusions: Treatment of asymptomatic, full thickness rotator cuff tear (Evidence: pg no: 16, L535)
Deltoid or rotator cuff paralysis (Evidence: pg no: 16, L536)
Use of xenografts or biologic scaffold for augmentation or bridging reconstruction (Evidence: pg no: 16, L537)
Use of platelet rich plasma or other biologics (Evidence: pg no: 16, L538)
Concomitant subacromial decompression/acromioplasty (Evidence: pg no: 16, L539)

codes.description: Repair of ruptured musculotendinous cuff (eg, rotator cuff) open; acute (Evidence: pg no: 20, L707)
Repair of ruptured musculotendinous cuff (eg, rotator cuff) open; chronic (Evidence: pg no: 20, L708)
Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; with rotator cuff repair (Evidence: pg no: 21, L740)

full_source.notes: For primary rotator cuff repair, adherence to a tobacco cessation program resulting in abstinence from tobacco for at least 6 weeks prior to surgery is strongly recommended. (Evidence: pg no: 14, L462-L463)

names: Diagnostic Arthroscopy (Evidence: pg no: 4, L152)
full_source.description: Diagnostic arthroscopy as a stand-alone procedure for evaluation of shoulder pathology when advanced imaging is inconclusive (Evidence: pg no: 4, L154-L155)
full_source.scope: Stand-alone diagnostic procedure (Evidence: pg no: 4, L154-L155)

documentation: Function-limiting pain for at least six (6) months in duration (Evidence: pg no: 4, L156-L157)
Abnormal shoulder physical examination findings compared to non-involved side including functionally limited range of motion or measurable loss in strength (Evidence: pg no: 4, L158-L161)
Positive Neer Impingement Test or Hawkins-Kennedy Impingement Test (Evidence: pg no: 4, L162)
Failure of provider-directed non-surgical management for at least three (3) months in duration (Evidence: pg no: 4, L163-L164)
Advanced diagnostic imaging study (e.g., MRI, CT) is inconclusive for internal derangement/pathology (Evidence: pg no: 4, L165)

Other potential pathological conditions have been excluded including fracture, thoracic outlet syndrome, brachial plexus disorders, referred neck pain and advanced glenohumeral osteoarthritis (Evidence: pg no: 4, L166-L168)

exclusions: Any other indication or condition (Evidence: pg no: 5, L171-L172)
In-office diagnostic arthroscopy (e.g., Mi-Eye™, VisionScope®) - considered experimental, investigational, or unproven (Evidence: pg no: 5, L175-L176)

codes.description: Arthroscopy, shoulder, diagnostic, with or without synovial biopsy (separate procedure) (Evidence: pg no: 13, L556)

full_source.notes: Considered medically necessary only when ALL criteria are met (Evidence: pg no: 4, L155)

full_source.section_title: Rotator Cuff Repair (Evidence: pg no: 7, L281)
names: Rotator Cuff Repair (Evidence: pg no: 7, L281)
full_source.description: Repair of Grade 2 or 3 partial-thickness or full-thickness rotator cuff tears with specific orthopedic test requirements (Evidence: pg no: 7-8, L283-L323)
full_source.scope: Arthroscopic or open rotator cuff repair (Evidence: pg no: 7, L283)

documentation: Function-limiting pain (Evidence: pg no: 7, L285-L287)
Individual demonstrates functionally limited range of motion OR measurable loss of strength of the rotator cuff musculature (Evidence: pg no: 7, L288-L291)

ONE or MORE positive orthopedic tests/signs including Drop Arm Test, Painful Arc Test, Jobe or Empty Can Test, External Rotation Lag Sign, Internal Rotation Lag Sign, Lift-Off Test, Bear Hug Test, Belly-Press Test, Neer Impingement Test, Hawkins-Kennedy Impingement Test, Hornblower Test (Evidence: pg no: 7-8, L292-L303)

Failure of provider-directed non-surgical management for at least three (3) months in duration, except for discrete traumatic event resulting in acute full-thickness rotator cuff tear (Evidence: pg no: 8, L304-L307)

Advanced diagnostic imaging demonstrates a Grade 2 or 3 partial-thickness rotator cuff tear (Ellman classification) or a full-thickness rotator cuff tear (Cofield classification) (Evidence: pg no: 8, L317-L320)

Other potential pathological conditions have been excluded including fracture, thoracic outlet syndrome, brachial plexus disorders, referred neck pain and advanced glenohumeral osteoarthritis (Evidence: pg no: 8, L321-L323)

exclusions: Any other indication or condition (Evidence: pg no: 8, L326-L327)
Superior capsular reconstruction using any type of graft - considered experimental, investigational, or unproven (Evidence: pg no: 8, L331-L332)

codes.description: Repair of ruptured musculotendinous cuff (e.g. rotator cuff) open; acute (Evidence: pg no: 13, L541)
Repair of ruptured musculotendinous cuff (e.g. rotator cuff) open; chronic (Evidence: pg no: 13, L542)
Reconstruction of complete shoulder (rotator) cuff avulsion, chronic (includes acromioplasty) (Evidence: pg no: 13, L544)
Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; with rotator cuff repair (Evidence: pg no: 14, L585)

full_source.notes: Conservative management requirement waived for acute traumatic tears, but required if fatty infiltration and/or muscle atrophy present (Evidence: pg no: 8, L308-L316)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroscopy and open procedures when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L373-L374)

documentation: For acute full thickness tear: Traumatic injury within the preceding 3 months with no preexisting shoulder pain (Evidence: pg no: 14, L467-L468)
Shoulder pain ≥ 4 on the VAS scale exacerbated by movement (Evidence: pg no: 14, L469)
Weakness of rotator cuff muscle(s) (Evidence: pg no: 14, L470)

Physical exam demonstrating a positive response to at least ONE of the following tests: Drop arm test, Painful arc test, Full/empty can test, Weakness of external/internal rotation (Evidence: pg no: 14, L471-L475)
Advanced imaging confirms features of an acute full thickness or high-grade partial tear (Evidence: pg no: 14, L476)

exclusions: Treatment of asymptomatic, full thickness rotator cuff tear (Evidence: pg no: 16, L535)
Deltoid or rotator cuff paralysis (Evidence: pg no: 16, L536)
Use of xenografts or biologic scaffold for augmentation or bridging reconstruction (Evidence: pg no: 16, L537)
Use of platelet rich plasma or other biologics (Evidence: pg no: 16, L538)
Concomitant subacromial decompression/acromioplasty (Evidence: pg no: 16, L539)

codes.description: Repair of ruptured musculotendinous cuff (eg, rotator cuff) open; acute (Evidence: pg no: 20, L707)
Repair of ruptured musculotendinous cuff (eg, rotator cuff) open; chronic (Evidence: pg no: 20, L708)
Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; with rotator cuff repair (Evidence: pg no: 21, L740)

full_source.notes: For primary rotator cuff repair, adherence to a tobacco cessation program resulting in abstinence from tobacco for at least 6 weeks prior to surgery is strongly recommended. (Evidence: pg no: 14, L462-L463)

original_chart:
OPERATIVE REPORT

Patient Name: Kevin Sanders
MRN: 765432198
Date of Service: June 25, 2025
Surgeon: Dr. Nicole Adams, MD

PROCEDURES PERFORMED:
1. Arthroscopic subacromial decompression, right shoulder
2. Arthroscopic debridement of partial-thickness rotator cuff tear, right shoulder

INDICATIONS:
54-year-old male with chronic impingement symptoms and partial-thickness supraspinatus tear not improved with therapy and injections.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
1. Shoulder impingement syndrome, right shoulder
2. Partial-thickness rotator cuff tear, right shoulder

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Same as above.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
With the patient in beach chair position, diagnostic arthroscopy identified fraying of the bursal surface of the supraspinatus tendon without full-thickness involvement. Subacromial space was accessed and thickened bursa removed. Soft tissue debridement performed along the anterolateral acromion. Partial articular-side cuff fibers were smoothed to stable tissue.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: 40 mL.
COMPLICATIONS: None.
DRAINS: None.

IMPLANTS:
None.

POSTOPERATIVE PLAN:
Sling for comfort. Ice therapy. Follow-up in 10 days for wound check. Therapy to start once pain controlled.

After thorough irrigation, all instruments were removed. The portals were closed with [AI ADDED: closure details] interrupted 4-0 nylon sutures. Sterile dressings were applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the recovery room in stable condition.

user_input_required.reason: Duration of symptoms is required to establish chronicity and medical necessity for surgical intervention
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific duration of function-limiting pain (must be at least 6 months for medical necessity)

user_input_required.reason: Pain severity documentation is required to establish functional impact and medical necessity
user_input_required.suggestion: Document pain severity using VAS scale (0-10)

user_input_required.reason: Specific conservative management details are required to establish that appropriate non-surgical options were attempted before surgery
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific types of conservative management (physical therapy, NSAIDs, activity modification, injections), duration (at least 3 months required), and outcomes

user_input_required.reason: Objective measurements comparing affected vs. unaffected side are required to document functional impairment
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific range of motion measurements for both shoulders (forward flexion, abduction, internal/external rotation in degrees)

user_input_required.reason: Objective strength measurements are required to document functional impairment
user_input_required.suggestion: Document rotator cuff muscle strength using 0-5 scale for relevant muscle groups

user_input_required.reason: Specific orthopedic test results are required to document impingement and rotator cuff pathology
user_input_required.suggestion: Document results of Neer impingement test, Hawkins-Kennedy test, painful arc test, empty/full can test, and other relevant tests

user_input_required.reason: Specific imaging findings are required to document pathology supporting surgical intervention
user_input_required.suggestion: Document MRI findings including location and characteristics of partial-thickness tear with classification (e.g., Ellman classification), presence of subacromial spurring, and other relevant pathology

user_input_required.reason: Specific tear dimensions are required to document extent of pathology
user_input_required.suggestion: Document dimensions of partial-thickness tear in mm or percentage of tendon thickness

user_input_required.reason: Documentation of specific functional limitations is required to establish medical necessity
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific activities of daily living affected by the condition

recommendations.recommendation: Document specific duration of conservative management (minimum 3-6 months required)
Document specific orthopedic test results (Neer, Hawkins-Kennedy, painful arc, etc.)
Document pain severity using VAS scale (0-10)
Include specific MRI findings with tear classification
Document comparison of affected vs. unaffected shoulder (ROM, strength)
Document specific activities of daily living affected by condition

compliance_impact.before: Original documentation lacked critical elements required by all payers including pain duration, physical examination findings, orthopedic test results, conservative management details, and advanced imaging findings. The operative report contained minimal preoperative information and lacked structured sections for history, physical examination, and imaging findings.
compliance_impact.after: With physician input to complete the identified gaps, the improved documentation will meet medical necessity criteria for all payers by including comprehensive documentation of: 1) pain duration and severity, 2) detailed physical examination with specific orthopedic tests, 3) conservative management details with duration and outcomes, 4) advanced imaging findings supporting surgical intervention, and 5) detailed intraoperative findings with specific tear characteristics.
key_changes: Added structured sections for History of Present Illness, Physical Examination, and Imaging Findings
Enhanced Indications section with pain duration, severity, and conservative management details
Added specific orthopedic test placeholders for physician input
Expanded procedure details with comprehensive intraoperative findings
Added documentation of tear characteristics and dimensions
Enhanced postoperative plan with specific rehabilitation instructions
